zh.title: 飞鸟集 - 泰戈尔
item: 世界向它的爱人卸下浩瀚的面具，它变得渺小，如同一首歌，一次永恒的亲吻。
蝴蝶不以月来计数，而是以瞬间；但它的时间已足够。
让生命如夏花般美丽，让死亡如秋叶般静美。

zh.title: 如果你忘了我 - 聂鲁达
item: 我只想让你知道这一件事。你知道，这就是我：当我望向水晶般的月亮，或我窗前缓慢秋日的红枝，当我触摸炉火旁无形的灰烬，或木柴皱缩的身躯，一切都把我带向你，仿佛世间万物——气息、光芒、金属——都是一只只小船，驶向那等待我的岛屿。
而如今，如果你一点点不再爱我，我也将一点点不再爱你。
如果你突然忘了我，请不要寻找我，因为那时我也已经忘记了你。

zh.title: 第十八号十四行诗 - 莎士比亚
item: 我该把你比作夏日吗？你却更可爱、更温和：
狂风会摇落五月亲爱的花蕾，而夏天的期限也未免太短：
但你的永恒夏日将不会凋谢，也不会失去你所拥有的美丽，
只要人类呼吸，双眼还能看见，你就长存不朽，这诗也赋予你生命。

zh.title: 未选择的路 - 罗伯特·弗罗斯特
item: 两条路在一片金黄树林里分岔，我遗憾自己不能同时踏上两条路。
我久久伫立，极目望向其中一条，直到它消失在远方的树丛中。
我选择了那条行人稀少的小路，而这改变了我的一生。

zh.title: 吉檀迦利 - 泰戈尔
item: 在那里，心灵无所畏惧，头颅高昂；
在那里，知识自由；在那里，世界不被狭隘的家墙分割；
在那里，言语自真理深处涌出；在那里，不倦的追求张开双臂向完美伸展；
父亲啊，请让我的祖国在那自由的天国里觉醒。

zh.title: 希望是长着羽毛的东西 - 艾米莉·狄金森
item: 希望是那长着羽毛的东西，栖息在灵魂深处，
它唱着没有词的歌，从不停歇，
在风暴中它的歌声最甜美；而必定是极大的风暴，
才会惊扰这只小鸟——它曾温暖过无数心灵。

zh.title: 不要温顺地走进那个良夜 - 狄兰·托马斯
item: 不要温顺地走进那个良夜，老年人应在日暮燃烧咆哮；
怒斥吧，怒斥光明的消逝。
虽然智者在生命终点知道黑暗是对的，因为他们的话语未曾劈出闪电，
他们仍不肯温顺地走进那个良夜。

zh.title: J·阿尔弗雷德·普鲁弗洛克的情歌 - T.S.艾略特
item: 那么，让我们一起走吧，当暮色铺展在天空，
像一位病人麻醉后被放置在手术台上；让我们走过某些半荒凉的街道，
屋子里女人们进进出出，谈论着米开朗基罗。
我用咖啡勺丈量了我的一生。

zh.title: 论爱 - 纪伯伦
item: 当爱向你召唤时，跟随他吧，哪怕他的道路艰难陡峭。
当他的羽翼环抱你时，顺从他吧，哪怕他翅膀中隐藏的剑会刺伤你。
因为爱怎样为你加冕，也将怎样将你钉在十字架上；他怎样助你成长，也会怎样修剪你。
爱不给予除它自身之外的东西，也不索取除它自身之外的东西；爱既不占有，也不被占有，因为爱本身足矣。

en.title: Stray Birds - Rabindranath Tagore
item: The world puts off its mask of vastness to its lover. It becomes small as one song, as one kiss of the eternal.
The butterfly counts not months but moments, and has time enough.
Let life be beautiful like summer flowers and death like autumn leaves.

en.title: If You Forget Me - Pablo Neruda
item: I want you to know one thing. You know how this is: if I look at the crystal moon, at the red branch of the slow autumn at my window, if I touch near the fire the impalpable ash or the wrinkled body of the log, everything carries me to you, as if everything that exists, aromas, light, metals, were little boats that sail toward those isles of yours that wait for me.
Well, now, if little by little you stop loving me I shall stop loving you little by little.
If suddenly you forget me do not look for me, for I shall already have forgotten you.

en.title: Sonnet 18 - William Shakespeare
item: Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May, And summer's lease hath all too short a date:
But thy eternal summer shall not fade, Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow'st,
So long as men can breathe or eyes can see, So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.

en.title: The Road Not Taken - Robert Frost
item: Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, And sorry I could not travel both
And be one traveler, long I stood And looked down one as far as I could
I took the one less traveled by, And that has made all the difference.

en.title: Gitanjali - Rabindranath Tagore
item: Where the mind is without fear and the head is held high;
Where knowledge is free; Where the world has not been broken up into fragments by narrow domestic walls;
Where words come out from the depth of truth; Where tireless striving stretches its arms towards perfection;
Into that heaven of freedom, my Father, let my country awake.

en.title: Hope is the Thing with Feathers - Emily Dickinson
item: Hope is the thing with feathers That perches in the soul,
And sings the tune without the words, And never stops at all,
And sweetest in the gale is heard; And sore must be the storm
That could abash the little bird That kept so many warm.

en.title: Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night - Dylan Thomas
item: Do not go gentle into that good night, Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
Though wise men at their end know dark is right, Because their words had forked no lightning they
Do not go gentle into that good night.

en.title: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock - T.S. Eliot
item: Let us go then, you and I, When the evening is spread out against the sky
Like a patient etherized upon a table; Let us go, through certain half-deserted streets,
In the room the women come and go Talking of Michelangelo.
I have measured out my life with coffee spoons.

en.title: On Love - Kahlil Gibran
item: When love beckons to you, follow him, Though his ways are hard and steep.
And when his wings enfold you yield to him, Though the sword hidden among his pinions may wound you.
For even as love crowns you so shall he crucify you. Even as he is for your growth so is he for your pruning.
Love gives naught but itself and takes naught but from itself. Love possesses not nor would it be possessed; For love is sufficient unto love.
